cards.front: What does the slope of a V-I curve (V on y-axis, I on x-axis) represent?
cards.back:
Resistance (R)

Slope = ΔV/ΔI = R

Steeper slope = higher resistance

cards.front: How should an ammeter and voltmeter be connected to measure V-I characteristics?
cards.back:
Ammeter: IN SERIES with the component
Voltmeter: IN PARALLEL with the component

Ammeter measures current through; voltmeter measures voltage across.

cards.front: What happens if you connect an ammeter in parallel with a component?
cards.back:
SHORT CIRCUIT!

Ammeters have near-zero resistance. Parallel connection creates a low-resistance path, causing:
• Excessive current
• Blown fuse (if lucky)
• Damaged ammeter (if unlucky)

cards.front: What characteristics indicate an ohmic component?
cards.back:
Three criteria:
1. V-I curve is a straight line
2. Line passes through the origin (0,0)
3. Slope (R) is constant at all measurement points

Non-ohmic components fail one or more of these.

cards.front: What does R² (coefficient of determination) tell you about V-I data?
cards.back:
R² measures how well a linear model fits the data.

• R² ≈ 1.00: Excellent fit, clearly ohmic
• R² > 0.99: Good fit, likely ohmic
• R² < 0.95: Poor fit, possibly non-ohmic

R² = 1 - (unexplained variation / total variation)

cards.front: What is the least squares formula for resistance from V-I data?
cards.back:
R̂ = ΣVI / ΣI²

This minimizes Σ(V - RI)², the sum of squared errors between measured V and predicted V = RI.

cards.front: What is 'loading error' in electrical measurements?
cards.back:
Error caused by the measurement instrument affecting the circuit:

• Voltmeter draws current → reduces actual voltage
• Ammeter has resistance → drops voltage

Use high-impedance voltmeters and low-resistance ammeters to minimize loading.

cards.front: Why do we sweep voltage and measure current (not vice versa) when characterizing resistors?
cards.back:
Practical reasons:

1. Voltage sources are easier to control precisely
2. Power supplies are naturally voltage sources
3. Current is the dependent variable (I = V/R)
4. Easier to set safe voltage limits

For some devices (current sources), I is controlled and V is measured.

cards.front: If slope of V vs I is R, what is the slope of I vs V?
cards.back:
Conductance (G) = 1/R

G is measured in Siemens (S), formerly called 'mhos' (Ω⁻¹).

I-V graphs show conductance as slope; V-I graphs show resistance.

cards.front: How can you tell from a V-I curve that a component is a diode rather than a resistor?
cards.back:
Diode V-I characteristics show:

1. Exponential shape (not linear)
2. Threshold voltage (~0.7V for Si)
3. Very low current below threshold
4. Rapid current increase above threshold

Resistor: straight line through origin.
